importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article update, indicating when the latest developments regarding the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant power restoration were reported.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the power blackout at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, which is the longest since the war began and underscores the severity of the crisis.

keyTakeAways: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed that work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP), following the establishment of rare local ceasefire zones.
The ZNPP has been without off-site power for four weeks, the longest outage since the war began, forcing reliance on emergency diesel generators for over 20 days.
Both Russia and Ukraine have accused each other of causing the power outage: Ukraine claims Russia intentionally cut the supply to test reconnection; Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.

The restoration effort requires cross-side coordination and security guarantees, with the Russian-controlled plant stating that the Russian defense ministry ensures safety during operations amid active shelling.
The IAEA emphasized that off-site power restoration is critical for nuclear safety and security, and both sides engaged constructively with the IAEA to facilitate repair work.
This marks the tenth time the ZNPP has lost grid connection since the war began, highlighting ongoing vulnerabilities in energy infrastructure.
Russia has conducted strikes on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, including a two-weeks prior strike on a substation in Slavutych, causing a three-hour blackout at the former Chernobyl plant.
Ukrainian officials accused Russia of a 'deliberate strike' using over 20 drones, implying intent to endanger nuclear safety at Chernobyl.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine has been without off-site power for four weeks—the longest outage since the war began—forcing emergency diesel generator use. Work to restore power is now underway, following the establishment of rare local ceasefire zones, with both the International Atomic Energy Agency and warring parties acknowledging the importance of safe restoration. The IAEA emphasized that off-site power is essential for nuclear safety. Ukraine blames Russia for intentionally cutting power to test reconnection, while Russia attributes the blackout to Ukrainian shelling. Additionally, a recent Russian strike on a substation in Slavutych caused a blackout at the former Chernobyl plant, raising concerns about broader regional nuclear risks. The situation highlights the ongoing threat to nuclear safety in conflict zones due to military aggression and the occupation of critical infrastructure.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
